confusion_pairs.title: Elasticity vs Scalability

a.definition: Automatically add/remove resources to match demand (up AND down).

b.definition: Ability to handle growth by increasing capacity (often planned).

bullets: Elasticity reacts to demand changes; scalability supports long-term growth.
Elasticity is typically automated (autoscaling); scalability may be manual/planned.
Elasticity saves cost by scaling down after peaks.

confusion_pairs.title: Vertical vs Horizontal Scaling

a.definition: Add more power to one machine (CPU/RAM).

bullets: Vertical hits hardware limits; horizontal usually scales further.
Horizontal often needs load balancing and stateless design.
Vertical is simpler; horizontal is more resilient.

confusion_pairs.title: SaaS vs PaaS vs IaaS

a.definition: Use an application; provider manages nearly everything.

b.definition: PaaS: deploy code on a managed platform; IaaS: manage OS/apps on rented infrastructure.

bullets: SaaS = you manage data/users; provider manages app+platform+infra.
PaaS = you manage code/data; provider manages runtime/OS/infra.
IaaS = you manage OS+apps+configs; provider manages physical infra.

confusion_pairs.title: FaaS (Serverless) vs Containers vs VMs

a.definition: Run small functions on demand; provider manages servers and scaling.

b.definition: Containers share a host OS; VMs virtualize hardware with separate OS per VM.

bullets: Serverless is event-driven and scales fast; you focus on code.
Containers are lightweight but share a kernel; VMs isolate with separate OS.
Choose based on control needs, portability, and isolation.

confusion_pairs.title: Public vs Private vs Hybrid vs Community Cloud

a.definition: Shared provider infrastructure for many customers.

b.definition: Private: single org; Hybrid: mix; Community: shared by orgs with common needs.

bullets: Public is flexible and scalable; private gives more control.
Hybrid mixes environments; bursting is a hybrid technique.
Community targets shared compliance/mission requirements.

confusion_pairs.title: Shared Responsibility: Provider vs Customer

a.definition: Security OF the cloud (physical, core infra, managed services baseline).

b.definition: Security IN the cloud (identity, configs, data, apps—depends on service model).

bullets: More provider-managed (SaaS) = less customer responsibility for platform.
Misconfigurations are usually customer-side failures.
Always map controls with a responsibility matrix.

confusion_pairs.title: Hypervisor Type 1 vs Type 2

a.definition: Runs directly on hardware; common in data centers.

b.definition: Runs on top of a host OS; common on desktops/labs.

bullets: Type 1 generally has better performance and security isolation.
Type 2 inherits host OS attack surface.
Exam cue: enterprise = Type 1; personal workstation = Type 2.

confusion_pairs.title: VM Escape vs Resource Reuse

a.definition: Break out of a VM to affect host/hypervisor or other VMs.

b.definition: Residual data exposure when shared resources (memory/storage) are reallocated.

bullets: Escape is active exploitation; reuse is leakage due to improper clearing.
Mitigate escape with patching and hardening hypervisor; reuse with secure wipe/zeroing.
Both are multi-tenant risks.

confusion_pairs.title: WAF vs SWG vs CASB

a.definition: Protects web apps from HTTP(S) attacks (OWASP-style).

b.definition: SWG filters web access; CASB governs cloud app usage and data controls.

bullets: WAF sits in front of your web app; SWG sits between users and the internet.
CASB enforces cloud policies (DLP, visibility, access control) across SaaS.
Inline CASB can block in real time; API CASB monitors/remediates via provider APIs.

confusion_pairs.title: CASB Inline vs CASB API

a.definition: Sits in the traffic path; can block/allow immediately.

b.definition: Connects via SaaS APIs; good for visibility and after-the-fact remediation.

bullets: Inline = real-time control; API = broad visibility into SaaS data/events.
API CASB can scan existing files and permissions at rest.
Inline can struggle with unmanaged devices unless architecture supports it.

confusion_pairs.title: Block Storage vs Object Storage

a.definition: Raw disk-like volumes attached to compute; good for databases/VM disks.

b.definition: Stores objects with metadata via API; great for blobs, backups, static assets.

bullets: Block = low-latency, file systems; Object = massively scalable via HTTP APIs.
Object storage often supports versioning and immutability options.
Choose based on access pattern and performance needs.

confusion_pairs.title: Infrastructure as Code vs Configuration Drift

a.definition: Declare infra in code; repeatable builds and reviews.

b.definition: Actual environment deviates from the declared baseline (manual changes).

bullets: IaC reduces drift, but drift still happens if people change things manually.
Mitigate drift with policy-as-code, CI/CD checks, and continuous validation.
Treat infra changes like software: reviews, tests, rollbacks.

cloud_nist_definition.rule: Cloud computing is on-demand access to shared configurable resources, rapidly provisioned with minimal effort/provider interaction.
cloud_nist_definition.micro_example: Spin up a VM in minutes from a portal without calling the provider.

cloud_essential_characteristics.rule: NIST essential characteristics: on-demand self-service, broad network access, resource pooling, rapid elasticity, measured service.
cloud_essential_characteristics.micro_example: If billing is usage-based and capacity scales on demand, you're in cloud-land.

ondemand_selfservice.rule: On-demand self-service: users provision compute/storage themselves via portal/API, without human ticketing.
ondemand_selfservice.micro_example: Dev creates a database instance from the cloud console in 2 minutes.

broad_network_access.rule: Broad network access: services available over network via standard mechanisms (web/API) to many device types.
broad_network_access.micro_example: Access a SaaS app from laptop + phone using HTTPS.

resource_pooling_multitenancy.rule: Resource pooling/multi-tenancy: provider shares resources among customers with logical isolation.
resource_pooling_multitenancy.micro_example: Many customers run VMs on the same physical host, isolated by hypervisor controls.

rapid_elasticity.rule: Rapid elasticity: capacity can scale out/in quickly—often automatically—to match demand.
rapid_elasticity.micro_example: E-commerce adds 20 instances during sale, then drops back to 4 after.

measured_service.rule: Measured service: usage is monitored/metered and billed (pay-as-you-go).
measured_service.micro_example: You pay per GB stored and per compute-hour used.

cloud_benefits_agility.rule: Cloud boosts agility: faster provisioning and experimentation reduces time-to-value.
cloud_benefits_agility.micro_example: A team launches a test environment for a feature in an hour instead of weeks.

scalability_vertical.rule: Vertical scaling = scale up one node (more CPU/RAM). Quick but hits limits.
scalability_vertical.micro_example: Upgrade a DB VM from 4 vCPU to 16 vCPU.

scalability_horizontal.rule: Horizontal scaling = scale out (more nodes). More resilient but needs architecture support.
scalability_horizontal.micro_example: Add more web servers behind a load balancer.

elasticity_vs_scalability.rule: Elasticity is auto up/down for demand; scalability is ability to grow capacity.
elasticity_vs_scalability.micro_example: Autoscaling group shrinks at night (elasticity) while the company plans to double capacity for next year (scalability).

cloud_roles_csp.rule: CSP (provider) delivers cloud services and maintains core infrastructure security.
cloud_roles_csp.micro_example: AWS/Azure/GCP operate physical data centers and core cloud services.

cloud_roles_consumer.rule: Consumer uses cloud services and must secure configurations, identities, and data (varies by SaaS/PaaS/IaaS).
cloud_roles_consumer.micro_example: Your team configures IAM roles and encrypts S3 buckets.

cloud_roles_broker.rule: Broker manages use/performance/relationships between consumers and providers (think: middle layer).
cloud_roles_broker.micro_example: A broker aggregates multiple SaaS subscriptions and enforces policy/billing.

cloud_roles_auditor.rule: Auditor assesses cloud services for security/compliance (independent checks).
cloud_roles_auditor.micro_example: An external firm reviews your cloud controls and provides an attestation report.

cloud_roles_carrier.rule: Carrier provides connectivity/transport between consumer and provider (ISP/telecom).
cloud_roles_carrier.micro_example: A telecom provides the MPLS link from your HQ to the cloud region.

service_model_saas.rule: SaaS: provider runs the app; you manage users, data, and access policies.
service_model_saas.micro_example: Microsoft 365: you manage accounts and data retention; Microsoft runs the service.

service_model_paas.rule: PaaS: you deploy code; provider manages OS/runtime/platform components.
service_model_paas.micro_example: Deploy an API to a managed app platform; you patch your app code, not the underlying OS.

service_model_iaas.rule: IaaS: you manage OS, middleware, apps; provider manages physical hardware and virtualization.
service_model_iaas.micro_example: Rent VMs and you patch the OS, harden services, and manage firewalls.

service_model_faas_serverless.rule: FaaS/Serverless: run functions on events; provider handles servers and scaling. Watch permissions and secrets.
service_model_faas_serverless.micro_example: Image upload triggers a function that resizes it and stores the result.

deployment_public.rule: Public cloud uses shared provider infra with strong logical isolation.
deployment_public.micro_example: A startup runs workloads in a shared AWS region.

deployment_private.rule: Private cloud is dedicated to one org (on-prem or hosted). More control, less elasticity than public.
deployment_private.micro_example: A bank runs an internal private cloud for regulated workloads.

deployment_community.rule: Community cloud is shared by orgs with common requirements (e.g., government/health).
deployment_community.micro_example: Multiple agencies share a compliant environment with shared governance.

deployment_hybrid.rule: Hybrid mixes environments (private + public). Great for phased migration and burst scenarios.
deployment_hybrid.micro_example: Keep sensitive DB on private cloud while web tier runs in public cloud.

cloud_bursting.rule: Cloud bursting: run normal load privately, burst into public cloud during peaks.
cloud_bursting.micro_example: Retailer uses private cluster normally but bursts to public cloud on Black Friday.

centralized_vs_decentralized.rule: Centralized management improves consistency; decentralized can boost autonomy but increases policy drift risk.
centralized_vs_decentralized.micro_example: A central cloud team enforces guardrails while product teams deploy within them.

shared_responsibility_model.rule: Shared responsibility: provider secures 'of cloud'; customer secures 'in cloud' depending on service model.
shared_responsibility_model.micro_example: Open S3 bucket is your responsibility, not the CSP’s.

responsibility_matrix.rule: Responsibility matrix maps each control to provider vs customer ownership per service model.
responsibility_matrix.micro_example: For SaaS, provider patches app; customer manages user MFA and data classification.

third_party_vendors.rule: Third-party vendors add risk; demand evidence (reports, controls) and constrain access.
third_party_vendors.micro_example: A SaaS vendor must provide audit reports and support least-privilege integration.

audit_rights.rule: Audit rights (contract) let you assess vendor controls and require notifications/SLAs.
audit_rights.micro_example: Contract includes right-to-audit + breach notification timelines.

data_sovereignty.rule: Data sovereignty: data is subject to laws of the country where it’s stored/processed. Choose regions accordingly.
data_sovereignty.micro_example: EU customer data stored in EU region to meet legal requirements.

csa_ccm.rule: CSA CCM is a cloud control framework mapping common security controls across cloud services.
csa_ccm.micro_example: Use CCM to check coverage for IAM, logging, encryption, and governance.

nist_sp_500_292.rule: NIST SP 500-292 provides cloud reference architecture and roles/relationships.
nist_sp_500_292.micro_example: Use it to explain where broker/carrier/auditor fit in cloud ecosystems.

virtualization_concepts.rule: Virtualization abstracts hardware so multiple OS instances run on one physical host. Security hinges on hypervisor isolation.
virtualization_concepts.micro_example: One server hosts 10 VMs for different apps.

hypervisor_type1.rule: Type 1 hypervisors run on bare metal: better for enterprise performance and security.
hypervisor_type1.micro_example: VMware ESXi-like setup in a data center cluster.

hypervisor_type2.rule: Type 2 hypervisors run on a host OS: convenient for labs but adds host OS attack surface.
hypervisor_type2.micro_example: VirtualBox on a laptop running Windows/Linux.

vm_escape.rule: VM escape is when a guest VM breaks out and compromises host/hypervisor/other VMs. Patch and harden hypervisors.
vm_escape.micro_example: Exploit in VM leads to host code execution, impacting other tenants.

resource_reuse.rule: Resource reuse risks residual data leaks when shared resources are reallocated without proper clearing.
resource_reuse.micro_example: A new VM reads remnants of memory pages if not zeroed securely.

vm_sprawl.rule: VM sprawl = too many unmanaged VMs. It increases cost, patching gaps, and attack surface.
vm_sprawl.micro_example: Old test VMs stay online unpatched for months.

containerization.rule: Containers package app + dependencies while sharing a host kernel. Faster and lighter than VMs.
containerization.micro_example: Run microservices as containers orchestrated by Kubernetes.

container_isolation.rule: Container isolation is weaker than VM isolation because containers share a kernel; use namespaces/cgroups and hardening.
container_isolation.micro_example: A kernel exploit could impact multiple containers on the same host.

container_hardening.rule: Harden containers: minimal base images, non-root, signed images, patching, and runtime policies.
container_hardening.micro_example: Use distroless images + drop Linux capabilities + scan images in CI.

api_security.rule: APIs are the control plane of cloud. Protect with strong auth, least privilege, rate limiting, and logging.
api_security.micro_example: Use OAuth/OIDC tokens with scopes and enforce rate limits on public APIs.

waf.rule: WAF protects your web app from HTTP attacks (SQLi, XSS, etc.). It’s not a general web filter for users.
waf.micro_example: Put a WAF in front of your login portal to block common injection payloads.

swg.rule: SWG filters outbound web access for users (URL filtering, malware blocking). It’s not for protecting your app endpoints.
swg.micro_example: Employees’ browsers go through SWG to block malware sites.

security_groups.rule: Security groups are virtual firewalls controlling inbound/outbound to instances—stateful and rule-based.
security_groups.micro_example: Allow 443 to web servers, allow 3306 only from app subnet to DB.

vpc_networking.rule: VPC networking segments cloud networks into isolated virtual networks (subnets, routing, gateways).
vpc_networking.micro_example: Create separate subnets for web/app/db and route via NAT/IGW appropriately.

sdn.rule: SDN centralizes network control via software (controllers), enabling faster policy changes and micro-segmentation.
sdn.micro_example: Push a segmentation policy across dozens of virtual networks instantly.

iac.rule: IaC makes cloud repeatable and reviewable; treat infra changes like code with tests and approvals.
iac.micro_example: Terraform defines VPC, IAM roles, and security groups in version control.

microservices.rule: Microservices split an app into small services; secure with service-to-service auth, mTLS, and good observability.
microservices.micro_example: Each service has its own identity and only the needed permissions.

secrets_management.rule: Secrets management stores and rotates credentials/keys safely. Never bake secrets into images or code.
secrets_management.micro_example: App pulls DB password from a secrets vault at runtime and rotates monthly.

hsm.rule: HSM protects cryptographic keys in tamper-resistant hardware; useful for high assurance key protection.
hsm.micro_example: Root CA private key stays in HSM; signing operations happen inside the device.

block_storage.rule: Block storage is like an attached disk volume: great for OS disks and databases needing low latency.
block_storage.micro_example: Attach a volume to a VM and format it with a file system for a database.

object_storage.rule: Object storage stores blobs via APIs with metadata; great for backups, images, logs, and static content.
object_storage.micro_example: Store user uploads in object storage with versioning enabled.

storage_encryption.rule: Encrypt storage at rest and control keys (KMS/HSM). Misconfig + wide access defeats encryption.
storage_encryption.micro_example: Encrypt object storage bucket and restrict read to app role only.

storage_replication_availability.rule: Replication improves availability and durability; choose sync/async based on RPO/RTO and cost.
storage_replication_availability.micro_example: Store data across multiple zones for durability; replicate cross-region for DR.

casb_inline.rule: Inline CASB sits in the traffic path for real-time blocking and policy enforcement.
casb_inline.micro_example: Block uploading PII to personal cloud drives in real time.

casb_api.rule: API CASB connects to SaaS APIs for visibility and remediation of data already in the cloud.
casb_api.micro_example: Scan existing SaaS files for PII and quarantine risky shares.

cloud_misconfiguration.rule: Most cloud incidents are misconfigurations: overly-permissive IAM, exposed storage, open security groups, weak logging.
cloud_misconfiguration.micro_example: A storage bucket becomes public due to a bad policy—data leaks instantly.

logging_monitoring_cloud.rule: Cloud logging/monitoring is your early warning system: collect control-plane and data-plane logs, alert on anomalies.
logging_monitoring_cloud.micro_example: Alert when a new admin key is created or when bucket policy becomes public.
